description: Abuse of privileges by staff (insider attack)
details: [4.3.1] Threats regarding back-end servers related to vehicles in the field - Back-end servers used as a means to attack a vehicle or extract data

description: Unauthorized internet access to the server (enabled for example by backdoors, unpatched system software vulnerabilities, SQL attacks or other means)
details: [4.3.1] Threats regarding back-end servers related to vehicles in the field - Back-end servers used as a means to attack a vehicle or extract data

description: Unauthorized physical access to the server (conducted by for example USB sticks or other media connecting to the server)
details: [4.3.1] Threats regarding back-end servers related to vehicles in the field - Back-end servers used as a means to attack a vehicle or extract data

description: Attack on back-end server stops it functioning, for example it prevents it from interacting with vehicles and providing services they rely on
details: [4.3.1] Threats regarding back-end servers related to vehicles in the field - Services from back-end server being disrupted, affecting the operation of a vehicle

description: Abuse of privileges by staff (insider attack)
details: [4.3.1] Threats regarding back-end servers related to vehicles in the field - Vehicle related data held on back-end servers being lost or compromised ("data breach")

description: Loss of information in the cloud. Sensitive data may be lost due to attacks or accidents when data is stored by third-party cloud service providers
details: [4.3.1] Threats regarding back-end servers related to vehicles in the field - Vehicle related data held on back-end servers being lost or compromised ("data breach")

description: Unauthorized internet access to the server (enabled for example by backdoors, unpatched system software vulnerabilities, SQL attacks or other means)
details: [4.3.1] Threats regarding back-end servers related to vehicles in the field - Vehicle related data held on back-end servers being lost or compromised ("data breach")

description: Unauthorized physical access to the server (conducted for example by USB sticks or other media connecting to the server)
details: [4.3.1] Threats regarding back-end servers related to vehicles in the field - Vehicle related data held on back-end servers being lost or compromised ("data breach")

description: Information breach by unintended sharing of data (e.g. admin errors)
details: [4.3.1] Threats regarding back-end servers related to vehicles in the field - Vehicle related data held on back-end servers being lost or compromised ("data breach")

description: Spoofing of messages by impersonation (e.g. 802.11p V2X during platooning, GNSS messages, etc.)
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Spoofing of messages or data received by the vehicle

description: Sybil attack (in order to spoof other vehicles as if there are many vehicles on the road)
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Spoofing of messages or data received by the vehicle

description: Communications channels permit code injection, for example tampered software binary might be injected into the communication stream
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Communication channels used to conduct unauthorized manipulation, deletion or other amendments to vehicle held code/data

description: Communications channels permit manipulate of vehicle held data/code
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Communication channels used to conduct unauthorized manipulation, deletion or other amendments to vehicle held code/data

description: Communications channels permit overwrite of vehicle held data/code
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Communication channels used to conduct unauthorized manipulation, deletion or other amendments to vehicle held code/data

description: Communications channels permit erasure of vehicle held data/code
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Communication channels used to conduct unauthorized manipulation, deletion or other amendments to vehicle held code/data

description: Communications channels permit introduction of data/code to the vehicle (write data code)
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Communication channels used to conduct unauthorized manipulation, deletion or other amendments to vehicle held code/data

description: Accepting information from an unreliable or untrusted source
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Communication channels permit untrusted/unreliable messages to be accepted or are vulnerable to session hijacking/replay attacks

description: Man in the middle attack/ session hijacking
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Communication channels permit untrusted/unreliable messages to be accepted or are vulnerable to session hijacking/replay attacks

description: Replay attack, for example an attack against a communication gateway allows the attacker to downgrade software of an ECU or firmware of the gateway
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Communication channels permit untrusted/unreliable messages to be accepted or are vulnerable to session hijacking/replay attacks

description: Interception of information / interfering radiations / monitoring communications
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Information can be readily disclosed. For example, through eavesdropping on communications or through allowing unauthorized access to sensitive files or folders

description: Gaining unauthorized access to files or data
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Information can be readily disclosed. For example, through eavesdropping on communications or through allowing unauthorized access to sensitive files or folders

description: Sending a large number of garbage data to vehicle information system, so that it is unable to provide services in the normal manner
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Denial of service attacks via communication channels to disrupt vehicle functions

description: Black hole attack, in order to disrupt communication between vehicles the attacker is able to block messages between the vehicles
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Denial of service attacks via communication channels to disrupt vehicle functions

description: An unprivileged user is able to gain privileged access, for example root access
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - An unprivileged user is able to gain privileged access to vehicle systems

description: Virus embedded in communication media infects vehicle systems
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Viruses embedded in communication media are able to infect vehicle systems

description: Malicious internal (e.g. CAN) messages
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Messages received by the vehicle (for example X2V or diagnostic messages), or transmitted within it, contain malicious content

description: Malicious V2X messages, e.g. infrastructure to vehicle or vehicle-vehicle messages (e.g. CAM, DENM)
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Messages received by the vehicle (for example X2V or diagnostic messages), or transmitted within it, contain malicious content

description: Malicious diagnostic messages
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Messages received by the vehicle (for example X2V or diagnostic messages), or transmitted within it, contain malicious content

description: Malicious proprietary messages (e.g. those normally sent from OEM or component/system/function supplier)
details: [4.3.2] Threats to vehicles regarding their communication channels - Messages received by the vehicle (for example X2V or diagnostic messages), or transmitted within it, contain malicious content

description: Compromise of over the air software update procedures. This includes fabricating the system update program or firmware
details: [4.3.3.] Threats to vehicles regarding their update procedures - Misuse or compromise of update procedures

description: Compromise of local/physical software update procedures. This includes fabricating the system update program or firmware
details: [4.3.3.] Threats to vehicles regarding their update procedures - Misuse or compromise of update procedures

description: The software is manipulated before the update process (and is therefore corrupted), although the update process is intact
details: [4.3.3.] Threats to vehicles regarding their update procedures - Misuse or compromise of update procedures

description: Compromise of cryptographic keys of the software provider to allow invalid update
details: [4.3.3.] Threats to vehicles regarding their update procedures - Misuse or compromise of update procedures

description: Denial of Service attack against update server or network to prevent rollout of critical software updates and/or unlock of customer specific features
details: [4.3.3.] Threats to vehicles regarding their update procedures - It is possible to deny legitimate updates

description: Innocent victim (e.g. owner, operator or maintenance engineer) being tricked into taking an action to unintentionally load malware or enable an attack
details: [4.3.4] Threats to vehicles regarding unintended human actions facilitating a cyber attack - Legitimate actors are able to take actions that would unwittingly facilitate a cyber-attack

description: Defined security procedures are not followed
details: [4.3.4] Threats to vehicles regarding unintended human actions facilitating a cyber attack - Legitimate actors are able to take actions that would unwittingly facilitate a cyber-attack

description: Manipulation of functions designed to remotely operate systems, such as remote key, immobilizer, and charging pile
details: [4.3.5] Threats to vehicles regarding their external connectivity and connections - Manipulation of the connectivity of vehicle functions enables a cyber-attack, this can include telematics; systems that permit remote operations; and systems using short range wireless communications

description: Manipulation of vehicle telematics (e.g. manipulate temperature measurement of sensitive goods, remotely unlock cargo doors)
details: [4.3.5] Threats to vehicles regarding their external connectivity and connections - Manipulation of the connectivity of vehicle functions enables a cyber-attack, this can include telematics; systems that permit remote operations; and systems using short range wireless communications

description: Interference with short range wireless systems or sensors
details: [4.3.5] Threats to vehicles regarding their external connectivity and connections - Manipulation of the connectivity of vehicle functions enables a cyber-attack, this can include telematics; systems that permit remote operations; and systems using short range wireless communications

description: Corrupted applications, or those with poor software security, used as a method to attack vehicle systems
details: [4.3.5] Threats to vehicles regarding their external connectivity and connections - Hosted 3rd party software, e.g. entertainment applications, used as a means to attack vehicle systems

description: External interfaces such as USB or other ports used as a point of attack, for example through code injection
details: [4.3.5] Threats to vehicles regarding their external connectivity and connections - Devices connected to external interfaces e.g. USB ports, OBD port, used as a means to attack vehicle systems

description: Media infected with a virus connected to a vehicle system
details: [4.3.5] Threats to vehicles regarding their external connectivity and connections - Devices connected to external interfaces e.g. USB ports, OBD port, used as a means to attack vehicle systems

description: Diagnostic access (e.g. dongles in OBD port) used to facilitate an attack, e.g. manipulate vehicle parameters (directly or indirectly)
details: [4.3.5] Threats to vehicles regarding their external connectivity and connections - Devices connected to external interfaces e.g. USB ports, OBD port, used as a means to attack vehicle systems

description: Extraction of copyright or proprietary software from vehicle systems (product piracy)
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Extraction of vehicle data/code

description: Unauthorized access to the owner’s privacy information such as personal identity, payment account information, address book information, location information, vehicle’s electronic ID, etc.
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Extraction of vehicle data/code

description: Extraction of cryptographic keys
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Extraction of vehicle data/code

description: Illegal/unauthorized changes to vehicle’s electronic ID
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Manipulation of vehicle data/code

description: Identity fraud. For example, if a user wants to display another identity when communicating with toll systems, manufacturer backend
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Manipulation of vehicle data/code

description: Action to circumvent monitoring systems (e.g. hacking/ tampering/ blocking of messages such as ODR Tracker data, or number of runs)
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Manipulation of vehicle data/code

description: Data manipulation to falsify vehicle’s driving data (e.g. mileage, driving speed, driving directions, etc.)
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Manipulation of vehicle data/code

description: Unauthorized changes to system diagnostic data
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Manipulation of vehicle data/code

description: Unauthorized deletion/manipulation of system event logs
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Erasure of data/code

description: Introduce malicious software or malicious software activity
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Introduction of malware

description: Fabrication of software of the vehicle control system or information system
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Introduction of new software or overwrite existing software

description: Denial of service, for example this may be triggered on the internal network by flooding a CAN bus, or by provoking faults on an ECU via a high rate of messaging
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Disruption of systems or operations

description: Unauthorized access of falsify the configuration parameters of vehicle’s key functions, such as brake data, airbag deployed threshold, etc.
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Manipulation of vehicle parameters

description: Unauthorized access of falsify the charging parameters, such as charging voltage, charging power, battery temperature, etc.
details: [4.3.6] Threats to vehicle data/code - Manipulation of vehicle parameters

description: Combination of short encryption keys and long period of validity enables attacker to break encryption
details: [4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Cryptographic technologies can be compromised or are insufficiently applied

description: Insufficient use of cryptographic algorithms to protect sensitive systems
details: [4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Cryptographic technologies can be compromised or are insufficiently applied

description: Using already or soon to be deprecated cryptographic algorithms
details: [4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Cryptographic technologies can be compromised or are insufficiently applied

description: Hardware or software, engineered to enable an attack or fails to meet design criteria to stop an attack
details: [4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Parts or supplies could be compromised to permit vehicles to be attacked

description: Software bugs. The presence of software bugs can be a basis for potential exploitable vulnerabilities. This is particularly true if software has not been tested to verify that known bad code/bugs is not present and reduce the risk of unknown bad code/bugs being present
details: [4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Software or hardware development permits vulnerabilities

description: Using remainders from development (e.g. debug ports, JTAG ports, microprocessors, development certificates, developer passwords, …) can permit access to ECUs or permit attackers to gain higher privileges
details: [4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Software or hardware development permits vulnerabilities

description: Superfluous internet ports left open, providing access to network systems
details: [4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Network design introduces vulnerabilities

description: Circumvent network separation to gain control. Specific example is the use of unprotected gateways, or access points (such as truck-trailer gateways), to circumvent protections and gain access to other network segments to perform malicious acts, such as sending arbitrary CAN bus messages
details: [4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Network design introduces vulnerabilities

description: Information breach. Personal data may be leaked when the car changes user (e.g. is sold or is used as hire vehicle with new hirers)
details:
[4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Unintended transfer of data can 
 occur

description:
Manipulation of electronic hardware, e.g. unauthorized electronic hardware added to a vehicle to enable "man-in-the-middle" attack
Replacement of authorized electronic hardware (e.g., sensors) with unauthorized electronic hardware
Manipulation of the information collected by a sensor (for example, using a magnet to tamper with the Hall effect sensor connected to the gearbox)
details: [4.3.7] Potential vulnerabilities that could be exploited if not sufficiently protected or hardened - Physical manipulation of systems can enable an attack
